title: I'm cool with Riot having their own little systems instead of tribunal to punish players.
body:
BUT THERE'S NO TRANSPARENCY.

I don't care how effective Riot SAYS their systems are. I want to SEE exactly how effective their systems are.
___

**Make a page on the website dedicated to showing a nice big list of players currently being punished for their behaviour detailing:**

**1. The Reason.
2. The type of punishment (i.e. Chat Ban, Account Suspension, Account Ban)
3. The duration.**
___

I want to be able to type in the name of the scumbag that was running it up mid the other week and see if they actually got punished. As it is now, the only system vaguely resembling this is the little notification telling me that someone I reported got punished. It doesn't say who. I doesn't say when. It doesn't say what punishment they got is or how long it's going to last. Was it the guy telling me to kill myself the last week, or was it the duo bot lane that thought 2v5'ing all game was a good idea?

replies.body:
My comment on another thread to someone saying we need tribunal:

> There's (other) systems in place. They work okay-ish. Fact of the matter, though, is that people don't report because they THINK the systems don't work. At this point, the system fails. Riot's biggest failure on this issue is that they aren't transparent enough. If people knew their report counted, player reports would be more accurate (i.e. selecting what they're reporting someone for), and detailed. They'd also be more meaningful in that they'd report people they know deserve to get punished and will likely get punished; they wouldn't just report someone out of spite.

Disagree 100% with the reply and the post. Why do you need to know who gets banned? Just because they popped up in your game once and ruined it, it doesn't mean they've done it before, could be their first or it could've been your attitude that caused them to act in such a way that disregarded the rest of the team. 
I'm not sure if the chat restriction is manual or automated, but I'm pretty sure for both, bans and chat restrictions, they both require a lot of reports from multiple DIFFERENT players for the punishment to go through.
What I'm trying to say is don't think you reported the player, that's going to be enough for punishment. They don't go through every single report that us players send.

It's mostly automated. A single report will flag the game, put it through the system that checks for key words and phrases, and then passes it onto Riot Player Moderation to have a final decision made if the offence is severe enough. It doesn't actually take lots of reports to ban someone.

I know exactly how the system works. I know that the system does it's job. But so many players on this server believe that because there's no tribunal that there's no player behaviour moderation on this server whatsoever. There's know way to see a comprehensive list of punished players and we've never had the tribunal system here.

I mean, disagree with me all you want but you actually have no clue how the system works. I'm not even the type of person to report people for every little thing - I report actual toxicity. When you report people sparingly like I do, the report holds more weight. From like 4000+ games I've maybe reported 200 people. Each of those reports is accurate and detailed with a nice long paragraph explaining the context in which the toxicity happened.

Except for "checks for key words and phrases" you're spot on with how the system works. You don't have to be swearing or using specific words, the machine learning of the automated system means it's pretty good at picking up context, and at passing on cases it can't accurately assess for manual review.

That said, I agree with idiotic shell about the list idea. Having a comprehensive list of people who have banned will do more harm than good. It leads to witch hunts and breeds more negativity in the end. 

HOWEVER, you also have a very solid point about the transparency. We really do need more statistics regarding bans/punishments, because as you so accurately pointed out, there is an attitude of "the system doesn't work I won't get banned" even though that isn't the case, effectively nullifying the effect of the threat, and leading many players to actual punishments before they realise their mistake.

There are a couple statistics floating around that look like this:
1. Only x% of players are ever permanently suspended.
2. x% of punished players never see a second punishment.

However I have misplaced my links for them so I'll have to reach out to some others for the specifics and get back to you. If memory serves the first stat is something like 0.01% and the second is up in the 90s

>there is an attitude of "the system doesn't work I won't get banned" even though that isn't the case, 

Let's face it, if the system did work, you wouldn't have people thinking that.

Negativity Bias, lack of feedback and "casual" toxicity plays a large role in this perception, and without specific statistics it is difficult to illustrate that fact to many players.

Negativity Bias is essentially the psychological factor that makes negative experiences stand out more in memory than positive ones, leading many to believe they encounter more toxicity than they really do. The easiest way to get perspective on this is to actually mark each game you play with how many negative players are in each one. For the vast majority of those who say "I have negative players in every single one of my games", the reality is more like one negative player per 10~ games (if that).
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negativity_bias

What I mean by "casual" toxicity, is those one off occasions, where someone gets incredibly frustrated/tilted/offended and lashes out. While it doesn't occur often for that one player, over the entire population the average player is bound to encounter a decent number of these over a long play time. These are instances where a player is unlikely to get punished, but still usually ruins an experience for other players.

All I can really say is, most of those people who say "the system doesn't work" and are negative players themselves, find out that the system works very quickly. Most of the people who hold this opinion are those affected by the above two factors, and who are **usually** largely unaware of the inner workings of the system, i.e they expect more feedback or transparency when someone is punished, and assume that not getting it means there was no punishment, when it is simply (what I would consider) something that is lacking in the system and isn't indicative of the system's effectiveness with regards to actual punishments, only feedback.

depends what your definition of "negative player" is.

in the context of this video game, i count "negative player" as anyone who afks/dcs (the reason for afk/dc is irrelevant), anyone who intentionally feeds, anyone who flames for no good reason (someone raging at a player intent feeding to me is 100% understandable), anyone who only plays for themselves and KDA and not for the team (this includes really stupid picks).

i don't know what elo you play in but you're just taking the piss mate. in low elo (majority of playerbase) this shit happens a lot more frequently than you and your riot overlords keep claiming. it legitimately is close enough to being "every game" for people to be saying it.

"1 in 10 (if that)" is a ridiculous claim. can't believe you actually think it happens in less than 10% of games. honestly it's starting to get insulting that you're claiming people are exaggerating by that much.
Seras has just bought into riot's lies, especially since he took the position with riot.

First of all, I have my disagreements with Riot, this particular issue is one of them. If I could have any one thing from Riot it would be more transparency with behaviour statistics because it is a real nightmare to answer some people here on boards.

Second, just as I cannot definitively prove to you they are not lies because I lack those stats, you cannot prove to me that they are lies, as you also lack those statistics. From where I stand, I see the system working, from where you are obviously you don't. It's just one of those agree to disagree kind of scenarios.

Third, not a he, and fourth, it's not a job, I don't get paid. I do this on my own time because I enjoy it and it's satisfying work for me. I have no obligations to Riot and am bound only by guidelines. It is a volunteer position.
You volunteer to kiss riot's ass, i don't see your point as to how that is different.

Feel free to point me in the direction of this ass kissing. Believing in something someone says doesn't make me an ass kisser. If I were to agree with you about the punishment system's effectiveness would that mean I was kissing your ass?

Shouldn't the obligation be on riot to show it is working?

I can show you a list of 800 games and the resulting 37% rate of afk/dc/troll.
but your just going to say your one person, law of large numbers etc

I can show you screen shots of intentional feeders match histories for 
large numbers of games with the account continuing to be active daily.

You can seeming just, say that I'm just a Negative person,
but no, I see people posting it doesnt work well, I see match records showing
it doesnt happen, I see no evidence from riot its working or being
worked on.

Maybe it just feels like its working for you, the law of large numbers 
means yes, some people will encounter less toxicity.
Maybe the reason it feels like a nightmare on the boards  is because 
4/10 games are bad experiences and riots done nothing apart from give us a
naughty word filter in the last 5 years.

Negative player by Riot's standards (and by my own) includes players who flame for ANY reason (defending yourself is fine, retaliation is not) and pretty much everything else you mentioned, along with the obvious ones like hate speech, racial slurs, scripting, mmr boosting etc.

I play in Gold/Plat but that is relatively recent. I've been in Bronze, and while there was certainly more frustration, the toxicity was not nearly as prevalent as many people claimed. Perhaps I was less influenced because I wasn't there for long, and still am because I don't play much ranked, I can't deny that I only have the one 1st hand perspective, and limited 2nd hand perspectives. 

To that however, I would challenge anyone who feels it is  in every game to mark every game, just with 10 Xs or Os, maybe with --s for those you believe to just be once off or non serious negativity. If nothing else, it would offer us both an excellent perspective.

I'm well aware that the frequency varies by elo, and I was making a general statement. Jason himself is in low Gold so would be unlikely to have a vastly different experience from myself at least as far as the elo variance is concerned.

**Some** people DO exaggerate by a lot, and often not intentionally, I'm not saying everyone does. For the most part, if those people stop and take a look, more often than not they are experiencing relatively infrequent but serious negativity rather than constant negativity. 

Again, it is a general statement, some people get very unlucky, some people have personalities that provoke those more inclined to negativity (which does not make it ok) and I cannot speak to what B5 is like (an environment that breeds frustration by it's very nature as the bottom rung).

>Negativity Bias, lack of feedback and "casual" toxicity plays a large role in this perception, and without specific statistics it is difficult to illustrate that fact to many players.

Lets just face facts, if toxic people got bans, then people would hear about it often enough from people who are getting these bans.

And don't be giving me this psychological bullshit when you can't even read the PR bullshit from Rito games who you are defending, because you should damn well know that they fuck up a lot and just try to PR it away.

now might be a good time to also bring up their dynamic queue bullshit. they created an environment (when they already knew how toxic their game is) where 4 people could bully one and said person gets punished for using certain language or whatever..

they never admitted the issue directly but the fact that they don't allow 4 stacks anymore in flex just proves it. yet they won't retroactively fix anything in regards to people's accounts. 

much easier and cheaper to just find relatively well known streamers or youtubers and say "we've got your back".

Premade reports do not have any extra effect than a solo report does. A valid report will still count against the player and and in valid one will still lower the reporters report weight.

Also worth noting that the system does not issue punishments based on keywords alone, the exception being hate speech/racial slurs etc.

They don't allow 4 stacks in flex because with the introduction of solo/duo queue there will not be enough solo players (especially on a small server like OCE) to fill that void.

They do in fact, remove punishments if they are made in error (with the exception of leaver buster penalties, as they cannot be removed), it just doesn't happen very often. On the other side, if a manual review of an account reveals negative behaviour that was not previously detected, they will face appropriate punishment.

I personally don't think it would create 'witch hunts' except potentially in the case of boosters and scripters (and any boosters/scripters should be permanently banned in the first place).

I think if I encountered someone who was flagged as being a toxic player or an intentional feeder I'd simply be more inclined to walk on eggshells around them rather than lash out at them.

The trouble is everyone reacts differently. 

For a decent chuck of 'neutral' players, seeing someone flagged as a negative player means they are free game to flame, abuse or troll. 

For many players, just knowing they have someone flagged as negative in their game can ruin it for them, can mean the difference between giving up on a game or not, especially if said player does badly in the early game.

For positive players, it feels unfair to be teamed with those flagged as negative, and Prisoner's Island type deals do not promote the reform Riot wants to see, rather they simply breed greater amounts of more severe negativity.

Many players would simply dodge a match rather than play with someone flagged as negative, resulting in unstable queues and essentially stopping those players from playing at all. A stop gap solution would be to hide summoner names in champ select but really it's just not worth the trouble.

The negatives far outweigh the positives on this one unfortunately.

I think you misunderstand. It would only show players that are currently being punished - it wouldn't permanently flag them. If you're banned or suspended then you won't even be in a lobby with teammates looking up your suspension in the first place.

I never meant to imply that I want players to be forced to play with a proverbial dunce cap on their heads.

If Riot really wanted to keep toxic players suppresses they should prevent players with chat restrictions or low priority queue (from AFKing) from playing ranked in the first place.

I did misunderstand yes :) Sorry about that one. 

Though that being what you meant, I would question what good a list like that would accomplish in such a circumstance. I guess the idea would be you could look up people you have reported to see if they have been banned, but that tends to encourage holding onto in game grudges when it would really be better to just let them go and move on.

As for preventing players with active restrictions from playing ranked, I don't disagree with you on that one. It is my feeling that if they were negative enough to be restricted int he first place, then allowing them into a higher stakes environment is not the best idea. I feel it would be a good punishment and a good reward when you do finish your restriction, as well as the obvious benefit of protecting other players in said high stakes environment.

That said, I can also see Riot's stance of minimising negative reinforcement (as positive reinforcement does so much better) and leaving the player's behaviour and actions fully in the hands of the player where possible, thereby making it completely their choice whether to reform/recognise their behaviour or not. I just don't totally agree with it.

I'll put it to you this way. Lets assume the player isn't AFKing, but actually Disconnecting. Disconnecting frequently enough to receive multiple punishments. They're clearly playing on a bad connection. They're clearly not checking their connection. By the time they get a suspension from Riot they've already ruined games for probably 72 players assuming it only takes ~4 Abandoned games to be punished, and that the 2nd time offence punishment is suspension. And yet Riot is still allowing them to play Ranked in the meantime.

The purpose of the list is simple - Riot gets to say "our systems work, as you can see by out substantial, tangible evidence that we now make visible to players".

Issue is riot doesn't care about actually curbing Toxicity, they care about looking like they curb toxicity, they are 2 different things that show very vastly different outcomes and come with different aims.

Curbing toxicity would result in a lower income base for league (more people getting banned means less people using money, this is especially a reason why level bots exist, if a person buys an account like that, they are likely to spend money on the game.) but on the flip side make the player experience better (which would likely result in a very slight increase in money coming in, no one likes paying for a game they don't have fun in)

Looking like they are curbing toxicity without actually doing much results in a higher income base for league, and gets people who don't understand the systems to be less toxic.

The issues though are massive.

Because we all know there are so many people that resort to feeding and trolling instantly when shit goes wrong, that's because the system isn't designed to stop them, if it were, they would get chat restricted early on, and probably actually fix their behaviour.

The other issue being that most bans are PR stunts, and the ones that backfire can have massive consequences. 

2 examples come immediately to mind.
Tyler1
AdellaideSkyhart

Both had similar things happen, their ban's were used as PR stunts, one was a heavily offensive ban on someone starting to reform but gaining popularity, which is funny because he still plays the game to this day even with a multiple account perma ban.

The other was a complete fuck up by riot, in which had to be made a PR stunt to try and explain the fact that their system doesn't make sense, these bans on this player should never have happened, but did anyway.

These 2 bans just highlight a shotty system based on inaction that looks like action.

And the worst issue is that these manual audits that are being done now, are being done to completely different standards then the automated system or Tribunal ever were at, my previous 14 day ban is an example.
